ETYMOLOGY: Variant of 'master', first used as a title of respect before a proper name or title.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Noun | A conventional title of respect
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A title used before the surname, first name, or full name of a man, corresponding to the abbreviation 'Mr.'
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 用于男士姓氏、名字或全名之前的称谓，对应缩写 'Mr.'
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Mister Johnson requested that the report be finished by Tuesday.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 约翰逊先生要求报告在周二前完成。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Used humorously, emphatically, or sometimes impatiently when addressing a man directly, especially when his name is unknown.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 直接称呼某位男士（尤指不知其名时），有时带有幽默、强调或不耐烦的语气。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Hey, mister, you dropped your car keys on the ground!
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 喂，这位先生，你把车钥匙掉在地上了！

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Noun | A formal or historical title
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: An informal or traditional title given to a person holding a specific role or rank, such as in the military or political address (e.g., 'Mister Speaker').
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 用于指称担任特定职位或等级的人的非正式或传统头衔（如在军队或政治场合，例如“议长先生”）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The non-commissioned officer was often called 'Mister' by the recruits.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 这名士官经常被新兵们称为“先生”。

REGISTER: Commonly used in dialogue and writing as the full form of the title 'Mr.'.
